title: Researchers gave AI bots their own social platform. It turned toxic.
text:
Business Insider tells the global tech, finance, stock market, media, economy, lifestyle, real estate, AI and innovative stories you want to know.
A team of researchers gave AI bots their own social platform — and it turned toxic.The chatbots split into cliques and boosted the most partisan voices. A handful of 'influencers' also quickly dominated the conversation, according to a study published last Tuesday by researchers at the University of Amsterdam.The researchers built a minimal social network with no ads, no recommended posts, and no algorithm deciding what users see.
The researchers also tested six interventions meant to break the polarization loop, including a chronological feed, downranking viral content, hiding follower counts, hiding user bios, and amplifying opposing views.None solved the problem. 'While several showed moderate positive effects, none fully addressed the core pathologies, and improvements in one dimension often came at the cost of worsening another,' the researchers said.
